--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Thu, 03 Jun 2004 20:30:04 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
> <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > I also think "bloat" is a misnomer here.  Bloat is a term from
> > Genetic Programming that referred to the accumulation of
extraneous
> > structure over the *entire population* that didn't help improve
> > fitness.  In general they were looking at a situaton where
everyone
> > was getting bigger for no good reason.
> 
> Well, this is something we've discussed before, and I'm not sure
we're
> going to come to a consensus on the issue.  But I'd argue that
"bloat"
> is an appropriate term to use if the *average* complexity of the
> population is increasing unnecessarily.
> 
> You say that I was only describing a situation where the mutation
> rates are too high.  Well, wouldn't you term that bloat?  If you
take
> a simple problem and apply NEAT to it, and have two runs, one where
> the mutation rates are double the other, NEAT will still solve the
> problem.  By the end of both runs, there will be a range of
> complexity, as you describe.  There will be complex networks and
> simple networks.  But in the run with doubled mutation rates, both
the
> *average* complexity and the complexity of the champion will be
> unnecessarily higher.
> 
> You would consider this bloat, wouldn't you? 
> 

Well sure I agree that is bloat, but it's only bloating because you
are adding structure faster than it can be evaluated.  In other words,
obviously there is some too-high structure mutation rate after which
NEAT can't absorb structure and test it fast enough to keep up.  In
that case, every species will grow and you will get bloat, and the
best the system can hope to do is keep the structure from screwing up
existing functionality.

But if you have a reasonable structural mutation rate, then NEAT will
exhibit the dynamic I talked about: expanding the range of
complexities in order to keep its options open.  That is not bloat in
my book, and is an appropriate response to stagnation.  

If you aren't sure what I mean by reasonable rate, it means that
structure is added slowly enough that it is still possible to find in
any generation enough genomes that have not had structure added so
that in the next generation the probability of two genomes with newly
introduced structure mating is low enough that all the offspring are
not products of such matings.  In other words, there's time for NEAT
to evaluate new structure's fitness effects before it starts
percolating through the whole population.

> > In other words,
> > addings more and more neurons during stagnation is creating space
> > for discovery, not tacking on an unalterable piece of junk.
> 
> But it could be tacking on an awful lot of superflous structure that
> is slowing down your search, couldn't it?
> 

Again, it's kind of loaded to call it "superfluous."  You are assuming
what you're trying to prove in a way.  That extra structure may be
necessary, as Colin's been saying.  But I also wonder if it slows
anything down anyway.  In general the performance of anything
surviving in NEAT that has more structure is in the ballpark of the
performance of things with less structure.  In other words, you don't
end up keeping around extra structure that severely cripples
performance.  So where are you seeing the slowdown?  You are in
higher-dimensional space, but it's a partially optimized part of that
space that performs as well as the lower-dimensional solution.  It may
even be *faster* to optimize in the larger space since there are now
more degrees of freedom.  In other words, if search is stuck in
low-dimensional space, even if a tiny little solution area exists
there, it may be faster to just go ahead and add more structure to
work with, at least at the same time as keeping around your smaller
candidates.

ken
